WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


A hidden Antarctic shift unleashed the carbon that warmed the world
Source: ScienceDaily    Published: 2025-12-02 12:00:34

Around 12,000 years ago, the last Ice Age drew to a close. Global temperatures rose, the early Holocene began, and human communities gradually shifted toward more permanent settlements. A new study published in Nature Geoscience highlights how the Southern Ocean around Antarctica helped drive this major climate transition. The research team, led by Dr. Huang Huang of the Laoshan Laboratory in Qingdao and including geochemist Dr. Marcus Gutjahr from GEOMAR, set out to reconstruct how far Antarctic Bottom Water (AABW) extended through the Southern Ocean over the past 32,000 years. "We wanted to understand how the influence of Antarctic Bottom Water, the coldest and densest water mass in the global ocean, changed during the last deglaciation, and what role it played in the global carbon cycle," says Huang, who completed his PhD at GEOMAR in 2019 and now works as a scientist in Qingdao, China. Sediment cores and chemical fingerprints in the deep sea To tackle this question, the scientists examined nine sediment cores collected from the Atlantic and Indian sectors of the Southern Ocean. The cores came from water depths between about 2,200 and 5,000 meters and from locations spread widely across the region. By analyzing the isotopic composition of the trace metal neodymium preserved in the sediments, which reflects the chemistry of the surrounding seawater, they could reconstruct how Antarctic Bottom Water changed through time on the scale of tens of thousands of years. "Dissolved neodymium and its isotopic fingerprint in seawater are excellent indicators of the origin of deep-water masses," explains Dr. Marcus Gutjahr. "In earlier studies, we noticed that the neodymium signature in the deep South Atlantic only reached its modern composition around 12,000 years ago. However, sediments from the last Ice Age showed values that are not found anywhere in the Southern Ocean today. Initially, we thought the method was flawed or that there was something wrong with the sediment core. But the real question was: What could generate such a signal? Such an exotic isotopic signature can only develop when deep water remains almost motionless for extended periods. In such circumstances, benthic fluxes -- chemical inputs from the seafloor -- dominate the isotopic imprint in marine sediments." Stagnant deep waters, carbon storage and the last Ice Age During the last Ice Age, the cold and very dense deep water that currently forms around Antarctica did not spread as widely as it does today. Instead, much of the deep Southern Ocean was filled with carbon-rich waters that originated in the Pacific, a glacial precursor to today's Circumpolar Deep Water (CDW). In the study, CDW is described as carbon-rich because it circulates in the deep ocean for long periods with limited contact with the surface. This isolation allowed large amounts of dissolved carbon to remain locked in the deep ocean, helping to keep atmospheric CO2 levels relatively low. As Earth warmed and ice sheets retreated between roughly 18,000 and 10,000 years ago, the volume of Antarctic Bottom Water increased in two clear phases. These expansion phases occurred at the same time as known warming events in Antarctica. With more vertical mixing in the Southern Ocean, deep waters that had stored carbon for long periods were brought closer to the surface, allowing that carbon to escape into the atmosphere. "The expansion of the AABW is linked to several processes," explains Gutjahr. "Warming around Antarctica reduced sea-ice cover, resulting in more meltwater entering the Southern Ocean. The Antarctic Bottom Water formed during this transitional climate period had a lower density due to reduced salinity. This late-glacial AABW was able to spread further through the Southern Ocean, destabilizing the existing water-mass structure and enhancing exchanges between deep and surface waters." Previously, many scientists assumed that changes in the North Atlantic, particularly the formation of North Atlantic Deep Water (NADW), were the main drivers of shifts in deep-water circulation in the South Atlantic. The new results suggest that this northern influence was more restricted than earlier thought. Instead, the replacement of a glacial, carbon-rich deep-water mass by newly formed Antarctic Bottom Water appears to have been crucial for the rise in atmospheric CO2 toward the end of the last Ice Age. Southern Ocean heat, Antarctic ice loss and today's climate "Comparisons with the past are always imperfect," says Gutjahr, "but ultimately it comes down to how much energy is in the system. If we understand how the ocean responded to warming in the past, we can better grasp what is happening today as Antarctic ice shelves continue to melt." Because of its vast size and unique circulation, the Southern Ocean plays a major role in controlling the global climate. Over the past 50 years, waters deeper than about 1,000 meters around Antarctica have warmed significantly faster than much of the rest of the world's oceans. To work out how this rapid deep-ocean warming affects the ability of the ocean to absorb and release carbon dioxide, scientists must track physical and biogeochemical changes over long timescales and incorporate them into climate models. "I want to properly understand the modern ocean in order to interpret signals from the past," Gutjahr says. "If we can trace how Antarctic Bottom Water has changed over the last few thousand years, we can assess more accurately how rapidly the Antarctic Ice Sheet may continue to lose mass in the future." Paleoclimate data obtained from sediment cores are indispensable for this, offering insights into past climates that were warmer than today and helping to improve projections of future climate change. Story Source: Materials provided by Helmholtz Centre for Ocean Research Kiel (GEOMAR). Note: Content may be edited for style and length. Journal Reference: Cite This Page: Next-Generation Cancer Drug Found To Slow Aging and Boost Longevity in Lab Study A Surprising Number of Younger Women Are Getting Breast Cancer Fat Stem Cells Heal Broken Spines in a Breakthrough Study Scientists Discover Hidden Lion Roar That Could Help Save Lions Stay informed with ScienceDaily's free email newsletter, updated daily and weekly. Or view our many newsfeeds in your RSS reader: Keep up to date with the latest news from ScienceDaily via social networks: Tell us what you think of ScienceDaily -- we welcome both positive and negative comments. Have any problems using the site? Questions?
WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


Structural mechanism of the Retron-Eco7 anti-phage defense system
Source: Nature    Published: 2025-12-02 10:40:39

Thank you for visiting nature.com. You are using a browser version with limited support for CSS. To obtain the best experience, we recommend you use a more up to date browser (or turn off compatibility mode in Internet Explorer). In the meantime, to ensure continued support, we are displaying the site without styles and JavaScript. Advertisement Nature Communications volume 16, Article number: 10821 (2025) Cite this article Retrons are prokaryotic genetic elements involved in anti-phage defense and consist of a non-coding RNA, a reverse transcriptase (RT), and various effector proteins. Retron-Eco7 (previously known as Retron-Ec78) from Escherichia coli encodes two effector proteins (the PtuA ATPase and the PtuB nuclease) and degrades the host tRNATyr upon phage infection, thereby protecting host cells against invading phages. However, its defense mechanism remains elusive. Here, we report the cryo-electron microscopy (cryo-EM) structures of the Retron-Eco7 complex, comprising the RT, multicopy single-stranded DNA (msDNA), PtuA, and PtuB. The Retron-Eco7 structures reveal that the RT–msDNA complex associates with two PtuA–PtuB complexes, potentially inhibiting their nuclease activity and suppressing bacterial growth arrest prior to phage infection. Furthermore, the phage-encoded D15 nuclease acts as a trigger for the Retron-Eco7 system and cleaves the msDNA bound to the complex, facilitating the dissociation of PtuA–PtuB from RT–msDNA. Our data indicate that msDNA cleavage by D15 is the initial step required for the specific cleavage of the host tRNATyr by the PtuA–PtuB nuclease, which leads to abortive infection. Overall, this study provides mechanistic insights into the Retron-Eco7 system and highlights the diversity of prokaryotic anti-phage defense mechanisms. Prokaryotes have evolved a variety of defense mechanisms to combat foreign nucleic acids, such as phages and plasmids1,2,3,4. Some of these systems, including restriction-modification systems and CRISPR-Cas adaptive immune systems, directly target and eliminate invading nucleic acids5,6. In contrast, abortive infection systems induce cell dormancy or death upon infection, thereby preventing phage propagation and protecting the cell population7. Retrons are prokaryotic genetic elements consisting of a non-coding RNA (ncRNA), a reverse transcriptase (RT), and diverse effector proteins, and are classified into 13 types based on the type of effector proteins8,9. The ncRNA contains msr and msd regions (hereafter referred to as msrRNA and msdRNA, respectively), with two inverted repeat regions (a1 in the msrRNA and a2 in the msdRNA)10 (Fig. 1a). The RT enzyme recognizes the a1 and a2 regions and reverse-transcribes complementary DNA from the 2′-OH group of the conserved guanosine residue (branching G) in the msrRNA, using the msdRNA as the template8,11 (Fig. 1a, b). Subsequently, the msdRNA is degraded by RNase H1, producing a unique RNA–DNA hybrid with a 2′-5′ covalent linkage (known as multi-copy single-stranded DNA (msDNA))11,12,13. Retron systems have been harnessed for genome engineering technologies, due to their ability to produce high copy numbers of DNA with customizable sequences8,14,15,16,17. a Schematic of the ncRNA and the msDNA in the Retron-Eco7 system. SL1–3 stem loops 1–3, bG branching G, oG opposing G. The ExoVII cleavage site is indicated by a yellow triangle. b Proposed reverse transcription mechanism of the Retron-Eco7 ncRNA. c Schematic of the Retron-Eco7 operon. ncRNA non-coding RNA, RT reverse transcriptase. d Anti-phage defense activities of wild-type (WT) Retron-Eco7, Retron-Eco7 with the PtuA mutation (D395A), and Retron-Eco7 with the PtuB mutation (H57A) against the SP15 and SP15m phages, evaluated by spot assays. E. coli cells transformed with an empty vector were used as the control. Assays were repeated at least three times with similar results. e Growth curves of E. coli cells expressing Retron-Eco7, PtuA–PtuB, dPtuA–PtuB (PtuA D395A), or PtuA–dPtuB (PtuB H57A). Data represent the mean ± SD of three biological replicates (n = 3). f Growth curves of E. coli cells harboring the Retron-Eco7 plasmid or an empty vector, infected with the SP15m phage at a multiplicity of infection (MOI) of 0, 0.1, or 10. Data represent the mean ± SD of three biological replicates (n = 3). g, h Ribbon (g) and surface (h) models of the Retron-Eco7 complex. ADP molecules are depicted as space-filling models. The first retron was discovered in 198410, but its biological functions have remained elusive for decades. However, recent studies revealed that retron elements function as toxin-antitoxin systems, with the RT–msDNA complex acting as the antitoxin and its cognate effector protein as the toxin, thus protecting bacterial cells against phage infections through diverse mechanisms18,19,20. In addition, recent studies of Retron-Eco1 (also known as Retron-Ec86) revealed that the RT–msDNA complex associates with its N-glycosidase effector to form a filament capable of hydrolyzing NAD(P)+, thereby providing mechanistic insights into Retron-Eco1-mediated anti-phage defense21,22,23. Retron-Eco7 (also known as Retron-Ec78) comprises an RT, a 144-nucleotide (nt) ncRNA, and two effector proteins, PtuA (the ATP-binding cassette (ABC) family ATPase) and PtuB (the HNH nuclease)18,19,24 (Fig. 1c). Recently, we reported that the Retron-Eco7 system cleaves the host tRNATyr and participates in anti-phage defense, which is inhibited by a phage-encoded tRNA25. However, the action mechanism of Retron-Eco7 remains unknown. In this study, we determined the cryo-electron microscopy (cryo-EM) structures of the Retron-Eco7 complex, consisting of one RT–msDNA complex and two PtuA–PtuB complexes. Our structural and functional data indicate that RT–msDNA associates with PtuA–PtuB, thereby suppressing bacterial growth arrest prior to phage infection. We further found that the phage-encoded D15 nuclease cleaves the msDNA within the Retron-Eco7 complex, facilitating the dissociation of PtuA–PtuB, which leads to host tRNATyr cleavage and ultimately abortive infection. Our findings provide mechanistic insights into anti-phage defense by Retron-Eco7 and highlight the mechanistic diversity of prokaryotic defense systems. To investigate the defense activity of Retron-Eco7, we expressed the Retron-Eco7 system, comprising the RT, the ncRNA, PtuA, and PtuB, in Escherichia coli (Fig. 1c). We then infected the bacterial cells with either T-series phages (T1–T7), the SP15 phage, which is highly similar to the wild-type (WT) T5 phage, or the mutant SP15 phage (SP15m), which lacks the anti-defense protein Rad and tRNATyr (SP-tRNATyr)25 (Supplementary Fig. 1a). Using spot assays, we subsequently examined the defense activity of Retron-Eco7 against these phages. Consistent with our recent study25, Retron-Eco7 protected E. coli against T5 and SP15m, but not SP15 (Fig. 1d and Supplementary Fig. 1b). Mutations of the putative catalytic residues in the PtuA ATPase (D395A) and the PtuB HNH nuclease (H57A) abolished the defense activity (Fig. 1d), suggesting that the enzymatic activities of both PtuA (ATPase) and PtuB (nuclease) are essential for Retron-Eco7-mediated anti-phage defense. Next, we monitored the growth of E. coli cells containing Retron-Eco7 after infection with SP15m. The expression of PtuA and PtuB, but not Retron-Eco7 (RT–ncRNA–PtuA–PtuB), inhibited bacterial growth without phage infection (Fig. 1e), suggesting that PtuA–PtuB and RT–msDNA function as a toxin and an antitoxin, respectively. A mutation in either PtuA (D395A) or PtuB (H57A) abolished the toxicity of PtuA–PtuB (Fig. 1e), indicating that the enzymatic activities of both PtuA and PtuB are crucial for growth inhibition. E. coli cells containing Retron-Eco7 exhibited normal growth under low multiplicity of infection (MOI) conditions, whereas their growth was inhibited under high MOI conditions (Fig. 1f). Collectively, these results indicate that Retron-Eco7 protects E. coli against phage infection through an abortive infection mechanism. To explore the defense mechanism of Retron-Eco7, we initially examined whether its defense activity is affected by the addition of affinity tags to the Retron-Eco7 components. We confirmed that the Retron-Eco7 system, comprising the ncRNA, His6-tagged RT, PtuA, and Twin-Strep-tagged PtuB, exhibits comparable activity to that of the untagged system (Supplementary Fig. 1b, c). Thus, we co-expressed the tagged Retron-Eco7 system in E. coli, isolated the complex using Strep-Tactin resin, and further purified it by size-exclusion chromatography (Supplementary Fig. 2a). SDS-PAGE and urea-PAGE analyses of the peak fraction eluted from the size-exclusion column revealed that the complex comprises the RT, PtuA, PtuB, and the msDNA (Supplementary Fig. 2a). Our analysis confirmed that the msDNA is an RNA–DNA hybrid consisting of a ~ 40-nt msrRNA and an ~80-nt msdDNA (Supplementary Fig. 2a), indicating that the msdRNA region in the ncRNA was reverse-transcribed by the RT to produce the msdDNA, which was then processed in E. coli, as previously described24,26. We determined the cryo-EM structures of the RT–msDNA–PtuA–PtuB complex (referred to as the Retron-Eco7 complex) in five distinct states (states 1–5) at 2.6–2.8-Å resolutions (Fig. 1g, h, Supplementary Figs. 2b–g and 3a, b, Supplementary Table 1, and Supplementary Movie 1). The cryo-EM structure revealed that the Retron-Eco7 complex consists of an RT molecule, an msDNA molecule, four PtuA molecules (PtuA.1–PtuA.4), and two PtuB molecules (PtuB.1 and PtuB.2), except for state 5, which contains an additional RT–msDNA complex (RT.2 and msDNA.2) (Fig. 1g, h and Supplementary Fig. 3a, b). PtuA.1 and PtuA.3 interact with PtuA.2 and PtuA.4, respectively, to form dimers, which in turn interact with PtuB.1 and PtuB.2, respectively. Both the msrRNA and msdDNA regions of the msDNA are recognized by the RT, while the msdDNA region is sandwiched by the two PtuA dimers. PtuA.1 and PtuA.2 interact with PtuA.4 and PtuA.3 via their coiled-coil domains, respectively, forming a tetrameric assembly surrounding the msdDNA. PtuA.1 also interacts with the RT and the msrRNA. Since the C-terminal domain of a PtuB molecule is sandwiched between the C-terminal domains of two PtuA molecules, the PtuB molecules (PtuB.1 and PtuB.2) can bind to the PtuA dimers (PtuA.1–PtuA.2 and PtuA.3–PtuA.4) in two distinct orientations (Supplementary Fig. 3c). Consequently, states 1–4 are structurally similar, except for the orientations of PtuB relative to the PtuA dimers. In state 5, RT.2 interacts with PtuA.4, msDNA.1, and msDNA.2 (Supplementary Fig. 3d, e). Similar to states 1–4, the DNA region of msDNA.1 is recognized by the two PtuA dimers, while the corresponding region of msDNA.2 is largely disordered and forms only a few contacts with the proteins, suggesting that a single RT–msDNA module is sufficient for the assembly of the Retron-Eco7 complex. Since the structures in states 1–5 are essentially similar and likely functionally relevant, we focus on the structure of state 1 unless otherwise stated. Overall, our cryo-EM analysis shows that the RT–msDNA complex binds to the two PtuA–PtuB complexes primarily through interactions between the msDNA and the PtuA dimers. The Retron-Eco7 ncRNA comprises the msrRNA and the msdRNA, with the 5′ region of the msrRNA (a1 inverted repeat) and the 3′ region of the msdRNA (a2 inverted repeat) forming a stem that ends with the branching guanosine (G0) and its opposing guanosine (G127) (Supplementary Fig. 4a). In the Retron-Eco7 structure, the msDNA consists of a 41-nt msrRNA (nucleotides (−58)–(−18)) and a 73-nt msdDNA (nucleotides 5–77), with nucleotides (−55)–(−50) in the msrRNA and nucleotides 72–77 in the msdDNA forming an RNA–DNA heteroduplex (Fig. 2a–c and Supplementary Fig. 4b, c). The present structure reveals that nucleotides 1–77 in the msdDNA are reverse-transcribed, whereas a previous study reported that the Retron-Eco7 msDNA contains a 78-nucleotide msdDNA (thus, Retron-Eco7 was formerly called Retron-Ec78)24. Similarly, the recently reported Retron-Eco1 structure showed that its msDNA contains an 85-nucleotide msdDNA21,22,23, which is one nucleotide shorter than previously reported27. These discrepancies might arise from incorrect estimations of msdDNA lengths in earlier biochemical studies24,27. In the present structure, the msrRNA contains a linker region (referred to as L1, nucleotides (−49)–(−40)) and stem loop 2 (SL2, nucleotides (−39)–(−18)), while the msdDNA contains stem loop 3 (SL3, nucleotides 5–64) and a linker region (referred to as L2, nucleotides 65–71) (Fig. 2a–c and Supplementary Fig. 4b, c). No densities were observed for nucleotides 0–(−17) in the msrRNA and nucleotides 1–4 in the msdDNA (Fig. 2c and Supplementary Fig. 4c), consistent with our data indicating that these regions were processed by endogenous nucleases in E. coli (Supplementary Fig. 2a). Overall, these observations confirmed that the msDNA in the Retron-Eco7 complex exists as a non-branched RNA–DNA hybrid, as previously reported24,26. a Nucleotide sequence of the msDNA. The ExoVII cleavage site is indicated by a yellow triangle. Watson–Crick and non-canonical base pairs are indicated by black and green lines, respectively. bG, branching G. b Structure of the msDNA. c Cryo-EM density map of the msDNA. d Structure of the RT–msDNA complex. e–g Close-up views around stem loop 2 (e), the RT active site with the YADD motif (f), and the flipped-out U(−49) in the msrRNA (g). Hydrogen bonds are indicated by dashed cyan lines. h Anti-phage defense activities of WT Retron-Eco7 and its mutants against the SP15m phage. The defense activities (PFU/mL) were evaluated by spot assays. E. coli cells transformed with an empty vector were used as the control. Data represent the mean ± SD of four independent replicates (n = 4), and no statistical analysis was performed. YAAA, the D187A/D188A mutant in the YADD motif. The RT in Retron-Eco7 (RT-Eco7) is structurally similar to other known RTs, such as the RT in Retron-Eco1 (RT-Eco1)21,22,23 and the RT domain of the Bombyx mori R2 retrotransposon (RT-R2Bm)28,29, and adopts a right-hand-shaped fold consisting of palm, finger, and thumb domains (Fig. 2d and Supplementary Fig. 5a, b). SL2 and L1/L2 of the msDNA are extensively recognized by the thumb and palm/finger domains, respectively, while stem loop 3 forms only a few contacts with the palm domain at its 5′ end (Figs. 2d, e and 3). The RNA–DNA heteroduplex is bound to the active site formed by the palm, finger, and thumb domains, with the conserved YADD motif (residues 185–188) in the palm domain located near the 3′ end of the msdDNA (Figs. 2d, f and 3). A structural comparison of RT-Eco7 with RT-R2Bm revealed that, in the Retron-Eco7 structure, the binding site of an incoming nucleotide is occupied by A(–47) in the msrRNA L1 linker (Fig. 2f and Supplementary Fig. 5a), while the template nucleotide U(–49) is flipped out from the heteroduplex and forms hydrogen bonds with Q46 (finger) and A69 (L2), with its nucleobase stacked between Y32 (finger) and A70 (L2) (Figs. 2g and 3). Thus, the present structure represents a termination state in the reverse-transcription reaction. To assess the functional relevance of the RT–msDNA interactions, we examined the effects of alanine mutations in the RT enzyme on the Retron-Eco7 activity using spot assays in E. coli. The D187A/D188A mutations in the RT active site abolished the defense activity (Fig. 2h), confirming the critical role of the reverse transcription activity in the Retron-Eco7 function. The thumb domain deletion (Δ235–313) also abolished the activity (Fig. 2h), indicating the functional importance of the interaction between the thumb domain and the msrRNA stem loop 2. In addition, the Y32A, R42A, and Q46A mutations moderately or substantially reduced the activity (Fig. 2h), highlighting the importance of the interactions stabilizing the reverse-transcription termination state. The residues that interact with nucleic acids through their main chains are shown in parentheses. While the msrRNA and msdDNA regions of Retron-Eco7 share sequence similarity with those of Retron-Eco1, the structures of their msdDNA regions differ substantially (Supplementary Fig. 5a, c). In the Retron-Eco1 structure, SL2 and L1/L2 of the msDNA are recognized by the RT in a manner similar to that observed in the Retron-Eco7 structure, with the RT active site occluded by an adenosine corresponding to A(–47) of the Retron-Eco7 msrRNA21,22,23 (Supplementary Fig. 5a). These structural findings suggest that Retron-RT-mediated reverse transcription terminates at a specific position in the msdRNA, with the termination site defined by interactions between the RT and SL2–L2 in the msrRNA, consistent with previous biochemical data22. However, there are notable structural differences between the Retron-Eco7 and Retron-Eco1 complexes. SL1 and the a1:a2 stem are flexible and disordered in the Retron-Eco7 structure, whereas the corresponding regions are ordered and interact with the RT in the Retron-Eco1 structure (Supplementary Fig. 5a). In addition, the orientation of msdDNA SL3 in the Retron-Eco1 complex differs from that in the Retron-Eco7 complex (Supplementary Fig. 5a). Together, these observations highlight both the conserved and divergent structural features among the RT–msDNA complexes in different retron systems. PtuA consists of an N-terminal domain (NTD, residues 1–63), an ATPase domain (residues 64–254 and 311–442), a coiled-coil (CC) domain (residues 255–310), a linker domain (residues 443–483), and a C-terminal domain (CTD, residues 484–550) (Fig. 4a, b and Supplementary Figs. 6a and 7a, b). The NTD comprises three α-helices and two β-strands. Two N-terminal α-helices in the PtuA.1 NTD interact with RT–msDNA, while those of PtuA.2, PtuA.3, and PtuA.4 are less resolved in the density map, due to the lack of interactions (Fig. 4b). The CC domain comprises two α-helices and mediates PtuA–PtuA interactions, while the CTD contains three α-helices and participates in PtuA–PtuB interactions (Fig. 4b and Supplementary Fig. 7a, b). a Domain structures of PtuA and PtuB. NTD N-terminal domain, CC coiled-coil, CTD C-terminal domain. b Structure of the Retron-Eco7 complex. PtuA.1/PtuA.2/PtuB.2 and PtuA.3/PtuA.4/PtuB.1/RT are shown as ribbon and surface models, respectively. c Close-up views of the ATP-binding site of PtuA.1–PtuA.2. A cryo-EM density map for ADP is displayed as a gray semi-transparent surface. Hydrogen bonds are indicated by dashed cyan lines. The Walker A and B motifs are highlighted in orange. d Anti-phage defense activities of WT Retron-Eco7 and its mutants against the SP15m phage. The defense activities (PFU/mL) were evaluated by spot assays. E. coli cells transformed with an empty vector were used as the control. Data represent the mean ± SD of four independent replicates (n = 4). ZnF, the C43A/C46A/C78A/C90A PtuB mutant. e In vitro ATPase activity of the WT and mutant Retron-Eco7 complex and PtuA alone, measured by an NADH-coupled assay. The purified Retron-Eco7 complex (either WT, PtuA D395A (dPtuA), or PtuB H57A (dPtuB)) or PtuA alone was incubated at 37 °C for 30 min in a reaction buffer containing 10 mM ATP and 0.3 mM NADH, and NADH oxidation was monitored by the decrease in absorbance at 340 nm. ATPase activities were calculated based on the NADH oxidation rates determined from five data points between 15 and 20 min. Data represent the mean ± SD of three independent replicates (n = 3). Assays were repeated at least three times with similar results. f–h Interactions between msdDNA and PtuA (f), PtuA and PtuB (g), and msrRNA and PtuA (h). i Anti-phage defense activities of WT Retron-Eco7 and its mutants against the SP15m phage, evaluated by spot assays. Data represent the mean ± SD of four independent replicates (n = 4). j Growth curves of E. coli cells expressing WT Retron-Eco7, its mutants, or PtuA–PtuB. Data represent the mean ± SD of three biological replicates (n = 3). The ATPase domain adopts an ABC ATPase fold with the Walker A (93-GNNGKGKT-100) and Walker B (391-IVLIDE-396) motifs (Fig. 4a, c and Supplementary Fig. 7b, c). Similar to other known ATPases30, the ATPase domains of PtuA.1 and PtuA.3 interact with those of PtuA.2 and PtuA.4, respectively, to form head-to-head dimers, which are further stabilized by their linker domains (Supplementary Fig. 7a, c). Interestingly, two ADP molecules are bound to the active sites at the PtuA.1–PtuA.2 interface, with the Walker A motifs engaging the ADP phosphate groups (Fig. 4c and Supplementary Fig. 7c). In contrast, one ADP molecule is bound at the PtuA.3–PtuA.4 interface, as the Walker A motif in PtuA.3 adopts an α-helical conformation rather than a loop conformation, for unknown reasons (Supplementary Fig. 7c). In the ADP-bound PtuA ATPase domains (PtuA.1, PtuA.2, and PtuA.4), N95 (Walker A) and E396 (Walker B) in one protomer form hydrogen bonds with H400/H402 and H400 in the neighboring protomer, respectively, stabilizing the dimer interface (Fig. 4c and Supplementary Fig. 7c). Notably, the N95A, E396A, and H400A mutations abolished the anti-phage defense activity in E. coli (Fig. 4d), indicating that the ADP-mediated dimerization of PtuA is essential for the Retron-Eco7 function. To further investigate the functional role of the bound ADP molecules, we measured the in vitro ATPase activities of the purified PtuA alone, the WT Retron-Eco7 complex, and those containing either the PtuA D395A mutation or the PtuB H57A mutation. The Retron-Eco7 complex, but not PtuA alone, hydrolyzed ATP to produce ADP, while the PtuA D395A mutation, but not the PtuB H57A mutation, abolished the ATPase activity (Fig. 4e and Supplementary Fig. 7d, e). These results indicate that PtuA functions as an active ATPase within the Retron-Eco7 complex. Thus, the bound ADP molecules are likely produced from ATP in E. coli cells via the PtuA ATPase activity within the Retron-Eco7 complex. Given that an E-to-Q mutation in the Walker B motif of the Rad50 ATPase abolished ATP hydrolysis while retaining ATP binding31, we examined the anti-phage defense activity of the Retron-Eco7 complex containing the equivalent PtuA E396Q mutation in the Walker B motif. The E396Q mutation abolished the defense activity in E. coli (Fig. 4d), indicating that PtuA-mediated ATP hydrolysis, rather than ATP binding alone, is necessary for the Retron-Eco7 function. These findings suggest that, within the Retron-Eco7 complex, PtuA continuously hydrolyzes ATP to produce ADP, which stabilizes the PtuA dimer and facilitates the interaction between RT–msDNA and PtuA–PtuB. To test this hypothesis, we analyzed the stability of the WT and mutant Retron-Eco7 complexes using size-exclusion chromatography. The WT and PtuB H57A mutant complexes eluted as single peaks (Supplementary Fig. 8a, b), confirming their stability. In contrast, the PtuA D395A mutation resulted in the dissociation of the PtuA–PtuB complex from the RT–msDNA complex (Supplementary Fig. 8c), indicating that the PtuA-mediated ADP production is essential for the interaction between RT–msDNA and PtuA–PtuB. This mechanism is reminiscent of that for the Rad50 ATPase, where ATP binding promotes Rad50 dimerization and enhances DNA interactions31,32,33. Unlike the PtuA D395A mutation, the PtuB H57A mutation did not cause dissociation of the complex but instead increased its aggregation (Supplementary Fig. 8b). These results suggest that the integrity of the PtuB active site is important for the stability of the Retron-Eco7 complex, thereby affecting PtuA-mediated ATP hydrolysis, consistent with our findings that the PtuB H57A mutation reduces the ATPase activity (Fig. 4e). Taken together, these data indicate that PtuA hydrolyzes ATP to generate ADP, thus helping to maintain the structural integrity of the Retron-Eco7 complex. PtuB consists of an HNH nuclease domain (residues 1–152) and a C-terminal domain (CTD, residues 153–216) (Fig. 4a, b and Supplementary Fig. 6b). The HNH domain of PtuB is similar to other HNH domains34, such as those of PtuB from the Septu defense system35 and Streptococcus pyogenes Cas9 (SpCas9)36,37 (Supplementary Fig. 9a). The HNH domain of PtuB contains a conserved histidine residue (H57) and resembles that of SpCas9 in its active, rather than inactive, conformation (Supplementary Fig. 9b–d), suggesting that PtuB in the Retron-Eco7 complex adopts a nearly active conformation. Unlike the other HNH domains, the PtuB HNH domain contains a zinc finger, in which a zinc ion is coordinated by C43, C46, C78, and C90 (Supplementary Fig. 9e). Alanine substitutions of these cysteine residues (C43A/C46A/C78A/C90A) abolished the defense activity (Fig. 4d), highlighting the functional importance of the zinc finger in PtuB. The CTD of PtuB contains three α-helices and interacts with the CTDs of PtuA (Fig. 4b and Supplementary Fig. 9a). The two PtuA–PtuB complexes associate with the RT–msDNA scaffold primarily through interactions between the msdDNA and the PtuA dimers, while PtuB.1 and PtuB.2 interact with PtuA.1–PtuA.2 and PtuA.3–PtuA.4 through their CTDs, respectively (Figs. 3 and 4b, f, g). Specifically, residues R126, R163, R171, and K180 of PtuA.1, PtuA.3, and PtuA.4 interact with the nucleobases or backbone phosphate groups of the msdDNA (Figs. 3 and 4f). Mutations of these residues resulted in mild (R171A and K180A) or substantial (R126A and R163A) reductions in Retron-Eco7-mediated anti-phage defense (Fig. 4i), confirming the functional importance of the PtuA–msdDNA interactions. Consistently, E. coli cells expressing Retron-Eco7 with either the R126A or R163A mutation in PtuA exhibited growth defects, as observed in E. coli cells expressing only PtuA–PtuB (Fig. 4j), highlighting the significance of the PtuA–msdDNA interaction in suppressing the toxicity of PtuA–PtuB. Among the four PtuA molecules, PtuA.1 interacts with the msrRNA sugar-phosphate backbone, with its NTD contacting both stem loop 2 and the linker region in the msrRNA (Figs. 3 and 4h). Deletion of the two N-terminal α-helices (residues 3–36) of PtuA abolished the anti-phage defense activity (Fig. 4i), underscoring the functional importance of the PtuA–msrRNA interaction. E471 of PtuA.1 and D521, K526, and R533 of PtuA.2 form salt bridges with R160, R49, E200, and E192 of PtuB.2, respectively (Fig. 4g). The D521R mutation, but not E471R, K526E, and R533E, in PtuA reduced the anti-phage defense activity (Fig. 4i), confirming the functional importance of the PtuA–PtuB interaction. Deletions of the PtuA CC domain (residues 260–305), PtuA CTD (residues 484–550), and PtuB CTD (residues 135–216) also reduced the defense activity (Fig. 4i), suggesting that these domains are essential for the complex formation. Collectively, these data demonstrate that the formation of the RT–msDNA–PtuA–PtuB complex is essential for Retron-Eco7-mediated anti-phage defense. Our recent study indicated that E. coli tRNATyr (Ec-tRNATyr) is degraded by the Retron-Eco7 system upon phage infection, leading to abortive infection25. To investigate whether Ec-tRNATyr is cleaved by the Retron-Eco7 system, we infected E. coli cells (with or without Retron-Eco7) with the SP15m phage, extracted total RNA from the cells at 20 min post infection, and detected Ec-tRNATyr using northern blotting. We observed cleavage fragments of Ec-tRNATyr in the lysates from SP15m-infected E. coli cells containing Retron-Eco7, but not in those lacking Retron-Eco7 (Supplementary Fig. 10a). In contrast, cleavage products were not detected in the lysates from SP15m-uninfected cells, regardless of the presence of Retron-Eco7 (Supplementary Fig. 10a). These results indicated that Ec-tRNATyr is cleaved by the Retron-Eco7 system upon phage infection. Mutations in either PtuA (D395A) or PtuB (H57A) resulted in the loss of Ec-tRNATyr cleavage fragments (Supplementary Fig. 10a), confirming that both PtuA and PtuB are necessary for tRNATyr cleavage. To determine the cleavage site of Ec-tRNATyr, we performed tRNA fragment sequencing on total RNA extracted from SP15-infected E. coli cells with Retron-Eco7, as well as from SP15-uninfected cells with only PtuA–PtuB. We detected an Ec-tRNATyr fragment downstream of U47 in the total tRNA from both cell types (Supplementary Fig. 10b), indicating that the Retron-Eco7 system is activated upon phage infection, with PtuA–PtuB cleaving Ec-tRNATyr between U47 and C48 in the variable loop region. Our recent study showed that SP15 phage-encoded tRNATyr (SP-tRNATyr) suppresses the Retron-Eco7-mediated anti-phage defense25. To explore its mechanism, we infected E. coli cells (with or without Retron-Eco7) with either SP15 or the tRNATyr-lacking SP15 mutant (SP15m), and then visualized Ec-tRNATyr, SP-tRNATyr, and E. coli tRNAGly (Ec-tRNAGly) using northern blotting. In E. coli cells with Retron-Eco7, Ec-tRNATyr, but neither SP-tRNATyr nor Ec-tRNAGly, was cleaved after phage infection (Fig. 5a). Both Ec-tRNATyr and SP-tRNATyr possess longer variable loops as compared to other tRNAs, such as Ec-tRNAGly (Fig. 5b and Supplementary Fig. 10c, d), consistent with the observation that Ec-tRNAGly was not cleaved by Retron-Eco7. Co-expression of Retron-Eco7 with SP-tRNATyr, but not with Ec-tRNATyr, in E. coli led to the loss of defense against SP15m (Fig. 5c). In contrast, co-expression of Retron-Eco7 with SP-tRNATyr mutants, in which the variable loop (A47–U59) was deleted or replaced with the 5-nt shorter loop of Ec-tRNATyr, provided defense against SP15m (Fig. 5c), highlighting the importance of the variable loop of SP-tRNATyr for Retron-Eco7 inhibition. Furthermore, E. coli cells expressing PtuA–PtuB with either Ec-tRNATyr or SP-tRNATyr exhibited normal growth (Fig. 5d), indicating that the overexpression of these tRNAs neutralizes the PtuA–PtuB toxicity. Collectively, these results suggest that SP-tRNATyr compensates for the decreased levels of Ec-tRNATyr, thereby leading to the suppression of the Retron-Eco7 anti-phage defense. a Northern blot analysis of Ec-tRNATyr, SP-tRNATyr, and Ec-tRNAGly. Total RNA was extracted from E. coli cells (with or without Retron-Eco7) with or without phage infection (SP15 or SP15m), and resolved by 10% denaturing urea-PAGE. Total RNA was visualized using ethidium bromide, while Ec-tRNATyr, SP-tRNATyr, and Ec-tRNAGly were individually detected using northern blotting. Assays were repeated at least three times with similar results. b Schematics of Ec-tRNATyr and SP-tRNATyr. The Ec-tRNATyr site cleaved by Retron-Eco7 is indicated by a yellow triangle. tRNA modifications are omitted for clarity. c Suppression of Retron-Eco7 by the phage-encoded SP-tRNATyr. E. coli cells were transformed with WT Retron-Eco7 together with either Ec-tRNATyr, SP-tRNATyr, or SP-tRNATyr mutants (V-loop deletion or chimera), and their defense activities against SP15m were evaluated using spot assays. The variable loop (G47–C60) of SP-tRNAᵀʸʳ was deleted and replaced with that of Ec-tRNAᵀʸʳ (G46–C54) in the V-loop deletion and chimera mutants, respectively. Assays were repeated at least three times with similar results. d Growth curves of E. coli cells expressing only PtuA–PtuB or co-expressing PtuA–PtuB along with either Ec-tRNATyr, SP-tRNATyr, or Ec-tRNAGly. Data represent the mean ± SD of three biological replicates (n = 3). To clarify how Retron-Eco7 detects phage infection, we infected E. coli cells containing Retron-Eco7 with SP15m and then isolated four escaper phages that evaded the Retron-Eco7 defense (Supplementary Fig. 11a). Whole-genome sequencing revealed that all four escaper phages contain point mutations in the gene encoding the D15 nuclease, which is essential for the expression of late genes in T5 phage genomes38 (Fig. 6a). Given that D15 exhibits endonuclease activity and that the escaper mutation (R86Q and R86L) is located near the active site in the D15–DNA complex structure39,40 (Supplementary Fig. 11b, c), we hypothesized that D15 cleaves the msdDNA within the Retron-Eco7 complex, allowing PtuA–PtuB to dissociate from the complex. First, we confirmed that the purified D15 protein cleaves both single- and double-stranded DNAs, but not single-stranded RNA, in vitro (Supplementary Fig. 11d, e). Next, we incubated the purified WT D15 or its mutants (R86L or R86Q) with the Retron-Eco7 complex and examined the cleavage of msDNA by urea-PAGE. The WT D15 cleaved the msdDNA, but not the msrRNA, within the Retron-Eco7 complex (Fig. 6b). In contrast, both mutants failed to efficiently cleave the msdDNA (Fig. 6b). Furthermore, the Retron-Eco7 complex treated with D15 yielded two distinct peaks corresponding to PtuA–PtuB and RT–msDNA on size-exclusion chromatography (Fig. 6c), indicating that D15-mediated msdDNA cleavage facilitates the dissociation of PtuA–PtuB from the Retron-Eco7 complex. To further explore D15's role in Retron-Eco7 activation, we measured the in vitro tRNA cleavage activities of the Retron-Eco7 complex with and without D15 treatment. Unexpectedly, the Retron-Eco7 complex did not efficiently cleave either Ec-tRNATyr or SP-tRNATyr, regardless of the D15 treatment, at least under our conditions (Fig. 6d and Supplementary Fig. 11f). Consistently, in contrast to the expression of PtuA–PtuB, the co-expression of Retron-Eco7 and D15 did not induce cell dormancy in E. coli (Fig. 6e). Whereas the PtuA–PtuB nucleases from the Septu system35 and the Retron-Eco4 system (also known as Retron-Ec83 or Retron-Septu)41 degrade dsDNA and ssDNA, respectively, the Retron-Eco7 complex exhibited almost no DNA cleavage activity (Supplementary Fig. 11g). Collectively, our data indicate that D15 is necessary but not sufficient for Retron-Eco7 activation, suggesting that additional unknown factors are required for the activation. a Spot assays of the isolated escaper SP15m phages. E. coli cells harboring the Retron-Eco7 plasmid or an empty vector were infected with the SP15m phage or the four escaper phages. Mutations in the D15 nuclease gene in the escaper phages are indicated on the right. b In vitro msDNA cleavage by the D15 nuclease. The purified Retron-Eco7 complex was incubated with purified WT D15 or its mutants (R86L or R86Q) at 37 °C for 1, 5, and 30 min, and then analyzed by denaturing urea-PAGE. The nucleic acids were visualized with SYBR Gold. Assays were repeated at least three times with similar results. c Dissociation of PtuA–PtuB from the Retron-Eco7 complex by D15 treatment. The purified Retron-Eco7 complex was incubated with the purified D15 nuclease at 37 °C for 10 min, and then separated by size-exclusion chromatography. The peak fractions (indicated by a red line) were analyzed by SDS-PAGE and denaturing urea-PAGE. The proteins and nucleic acids were visualized with CBB and SYBR Gold, respectively. Experiments were repeated at least three times with similar results. d In vitro tRNA cleavage by the Retron-Eco7 complex. The 5′-Cy5-labeled Ec-tRNATyr (200 nM) was incubated with the purified Retron-Eco7 complex (500 nM) with or without the purified D15 (500 nM) at 37 °C for 60 min, and then analyzed by denaturing urea-PAGE. The nucleic acids (msrRNA and msdDNA) were visualized with SYBR Gold, while Ec-tRNATyr was detected using Cy5 fluorescence. Assays were repeated at least three times with similar results. e Spot assays of E. coli cells expressing Retron-Eco7 (with or without D15), D15, or PtuA–PtuB. Assays were repeated at least three times with similar results. f Proposed model of the Retron-Eco7 anti-phage defense. Our functional and structural data suggest that, in the Retron-Eco7 system, RT–msDNA binds to the PtuA–PtuB effector nuclease and inhibits the cleavage of the host tRNATyr by PtuA–PtuB, while PtuA–PtuB dissociates from RT–msDNA upon phage infection, leading to the host tRNATyr cleavage and thereby conferring anti-phage defense through abortive infection (Fig. 6f). Our findings reinforce the concept that, in retron systems, the RT–msDNA and effector proteins function as an anti-toxin and a toxin, respectively, thus protecting host bacterial cells. The Retron-Eco7 complex structure represents the second example of a structurally characterized retron complex, enabling structural comparisons between different retron complexes. Notable similarities and differences exist between the Retron-Eco7 complex and the recently reported Retron-Eco1 complex21,22,23 (Fig. 7a). The ncRNAs of Eco1 and Eco7 contain similar msrRNA sequences but differ in their msdRNA sequences (which serve as templates for reverse transcription). In the structures of Eco1 and Eco7, the msdRNA regions are reverse-transcribed by the RT into msdDNA, forming an msrRNA–msdDNA hybrid. In particular, the RT–msDNA complexes in the Eco1 and Eco7 systems adopt similar reverse-transcription termination states. In both structures, the msrRNA–msdDNA heteroduplex is accommodated within the RT active site, with the terminal nucleotide in the msdDNA defined by RT–msrRNA interactions in comparable manners. In contrast, the msdDNA nucleotides outside the heteroduplex adopt distinct structures and serve as scaffolds to recruit their cognate effector proteins, highlighting the common principle that the RT–msDNA binds its cognate effector to suppress the toxicity of the effector prior to phage infection. However, the binding modes of RT–msDNA to effectors differ substantially between the Eco1 and Eco7 structures (Fig. 7a). In the Eco7 structure, one RT–msDNA complex interacts with two effectors (PtuA–PtuB), primarily through msDNA–PtuA interactions. In contrast, in the Eco1 structure, one RT–msDNA complex associates with a single effector (N-glycosidase), forming a dimer primarily through effector–effector interactions. Furthermore, the Eco1 dimer interacts with another Eco1 dimer through RT–RT interactions, thereby forming a filament structure. Consistent with these structural differences, RT-Eco7 lacks the α helix corresponding to the N-terminal α helix in RT-Eco1, which is essential for Eco1 dimerization. a Structures of the RT–msDNA–PtuA–PtuB complex in Retron-Eco7 (left) and the RT–msDNA–N-glycosidase (N-glyco) complex in Retron-Eco1 (right)22 (PDB: 8QBM). The RT–msDNA complexes are shown on the right side of the whole complexes for comparison. ADP (Retron-Eco7) and ADP-ribose (Retron-Eco1) molecules are depicted as space-filling models. b Structures of the Retron-Eco7 complex, the Septu PtuA–PtuB complex35 (PDB: 8EEA), and the Retron-Eco4 complex41 (PDB: 9E8Z). The structures are colored according to the protomers (upper) and domains (lower). Bound nucleotides, including three ADP molecules (Retron-Eco7), four ATP molecules (Septu), and two ADP molecules (Retron-Eco4), are shown as space-filling models. We identified the phage-encoded D15 nuclease as a trigger for the type I-A Retron-Eco7. Our biochemical data demonstrated that D15 cleaves the msDNA in the Retron-Eco7 complex, facilitating the release of PtuA–PtuB from RT–msDNA. Recently, George et al. reported that, in the type I-A retron system from E. coli FORC 82 (Retron-FORC), one RT–msDNA complex associates with two PtuA–PtuB effector nucleases to form a large complex similar to the Retron-Eco7 complex42. In addition, George et al. showed that the co-expression of the Retron-FORC system and D15 leads to msDNA degradation in E. coli, thereby inducing cell death42. These findings highlight the conserved role of D15 as a trigger protein among type I-A retrons. In contrast, in the type II-A3 Retron-Eco1 system, the phage-encoded Dcm methylase serves as the trigger and methylates the msdDNA in the Retron-Eco1 complex, likely leading to a conformational change in the N-glycosidase effector23. Subsequently, the effector enzyme hydrolyzes NAD(P)+ to produce a 5′-diphosphate ribose, potentially resulting in NAD(P)+ depletion and DNA ADP ribosylation, although the detailed mechanism remains unclear22,23. These observations reinforce the notion that msDNAs function as sensors of phage infection through diverse mechanisms. Recent studies showed that other retrons, such as Retron-Sen220 and Retron-Eco618, possess ncRNAs with distinct msdRNA sequences, utilize specific effectors with diverse activities, and detect different phage components, highlighting the structural and mechanistic variations among retron systems. Like the Retron-Eco7 system, the Septu defense system employs the PtuA–PtuB nuclease for anti-phage defense35. However, there are notable differences in their action mechanisms. First, PtuA–PtuB degrades the phage DNA in the Septu system, but cleaves the host tRNATyr in the Retron-Eco7 system. Second, Retron-Eco7 PtuA exhibits ATPase activity, whereas Septu PtuA lacks ATPase activity and functions as an ATP-binding protein, with the DNase activity of PtuA–PtuB inhibited by ATP binding. Third, the RNase activity of Retron-Eco7 PtuA–PtuB is triggered by D15-mediated msDNA cleavage, while the DNase activity of Septu PtuA–PtuB is enhanced by the reduced cellular ATP levels upon phage infection. A structural comparison of the PtuA–PtuB complexes from the Septu and Retron-Eco7 systems provides insights into their mechanistic differences (Fig. 7b). In both structures, the PtuA dimer binds to PtuB in a similar manner, but the PtuA–PtuB complexes adopt distinct oligomeric states. In the Retron-Eco7 structure, two PtuA dimers extensively interact with the msDNA, with their CC domains stabilizing the complex. In contrast, in the Septu structure, two PtuA dimers are bridged by a third PtuA dimer (lacking PtuB), without direct contacts between the first and second dimers. Consistent with these structural differences, Septu PtuA lacks a CC domain. These structural variations likely reflect the functional differences between the PtuA–PtuB nucleases in the two systems. However, it remains unclear why Retron-Eco7 PtuA–PtuB cleaves the host tRNA, while Septu PtuA–PtuB degrades the phage DNA, given that both PtuB nucleases adopt similar HNH folds. Unexpectedly, our data indicated that Retron-Eco7 cleaved tRNATyr in phage-infected E. coli cells, but not in vitro even after treatment with the D15 nuclease. Consistent with our findings, Wang et al. recently reported that Retron-Eco7 does not cleave tRNATyr in vitro, even after msDNA degradation by DNase I43. Wang et al. and Li et al. determined the cryo-EM structures of the Retron-Eco7 complex, comprising RT–msDNA, PtuA, and PtuB, which are essentially identical to our complex structure43,44. Furthermore, Wang et al. and Li et al. reported the cryo-EM structures of the RT–msDNA-unbound PtuA–PtuB complex in distinct stoichiometries (PtuA4–PtuB243 and PtuA2–PtuB144), demonstrating that PtuA and PtuB can form a complex after dissociation from RT–msDNA, although the stoichiometry of the functional complex remains unclear. To gain mechanistic insights into tRNATyr recognition by PtuA–PtuB, we used AlphaFold 345 to predict a structural model of the PtuA–PtuB complex bound to tRNATyr, based on the RT–msDNA-unbound PtuA4–PtuB2 structure. We obtained structural models of the tRNATyr-bound PtuA–PtuB complex, in which the active site of the PtuB nuclease is located near either the anticodon loop or the CCA end of tRNATyr (Supplementary Fig. 12). A structural comparison of the Retron-Eco7 complex with the tRNA-bound PtuA–PtuB complex suggests that RT–msDNA prevents the tRNA substrate from accessing the PtuB active site, and that the dissociation of PtuA–PtuB from RT–msDNA allows for tRNA recognition. However, we did not obtain a model where the PtuB active site is located near the tRNATyr variable loop containing the cleavage site identified in our RNA-seq analysis. Thus, how tRNATyr is recognized and cleaved by the PtuA–PtuB complex remains unresolved. Notably, the co-expression of Retron-Eco7 and D15 did not induce bacterial growth arrest, suggesting that additional factors are necessary for the full activation of Retron-Eco7. It is possible that unknown factors further facilitate the dissociation of PtuB from the PtuA–PtuB complex, activating the PtuB nuclease. While our manuscript was under revision, Wang et al. reported the cryo-EM structure of the type I-A Retron-Eco4 complex, comprising one RT–msDNA complex and two PtuA–PtuB effector nucleases41. Although the Retron-Eco4 complex is structurally similar to the Retron-Eco7 complex, it cleaves ssDNA, rather than tRNATyr, underscoring the functional diversity within type I-A retrons (Fig. 7b). However, the mechanisms of Retron-Eco4 activation and specific substrate recognition by the two type I-A retron systems remain unknown. Recent studies reported that the PARIS defense system also targets host tRNA and protects bacterial cells against phage infection46,47,48, illuminating the mechanistic similarities between the Retron-Eco7 and PARIS systems. Furthermore, phage-encoded tRNAs can neutralize both systems, highlighting their biological role in countering bacterial defense systems, as described in recent studies25,49. However, there are notable mechanistic differences between the two systems. In the PARIS system, AriA (the ABC ATPase antitoxin) and AriB (the TOPRIM nuclease toxin) form a supramolecular complex, and the phage-encoded Ocr protein promotes the dissociation of AriB, which subsequently dimerizes and becomes activated to cleave the host tRNALys47,48. In summary, this study revealed that the Retron-Eco7 system cleaves the host tRNATyr during phage infection and provides anti-phage defense through abortive infection. However, further studies will be needed to understand its mechanism of action, and particularly how the Retron-Eco7 system becomes activated and cleaves tRNATyr. The SP15 and SP15m phages were isolated and cultivated as previously described25 (Supplementary Data 1). For the spot assay, 300 μL of an overnight culture of E. coli (DH10B) harboring the indicated plasmids (Supplementary Data 1) was mixed with 10 mL of LB top agar (LB medium, 0.5% agarose, and 1 mM CaCl2) and poured onto an LB agar plate. For the spot assays in Figs. 1d, 2h, 4d and i and Supplementary Fig. 1b, c, 0.2% L-arabinose was added to the LB medium at the beginning of the culture to induce constitutive expression of Retron-Eco7. The phage solution was serially diluted tenfold in Sodium-Magnesium (SM) buffer (50 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.5, 100 mM NaCl, 5 mM MgSO4, and 0.01% (w/v) gelatin solution). Then, 3 µL of each phage dilution was spotted onto the bacterial lawn. Plates were incubated at room temperature until the spots dried and then at 37 °C overnight. Lysis zones (plaques) were recorded the following day. For Figs. 2h and 4d and i, plaque-forming units (PFU) per volume were quantified and plotted using GraphPad Prism 10 (GraphPad). E. coli cells containing the indicated plasmids (Supplementary Data 1) were grown at 37 °C overnight in LB medium. The overnight cultures were then diluted 100-fold in LB medium containing 0.1% L-arabinose and, if indicated, infected with phages at the indicated multiplicity of infection (MOI). A 100 µL aliquot of each diluted culture was transferred to a 96-well plate, which was sealed with a Breathe-Easy sealing membrane (Sigma Aldrich). Growth was monitored at 37 °C for 10 h with shaking, and OD600 values were measured every 20 min using a SpectraMax iD5 plate reader (Molecular Devices). Raw data were analyzed and plotted using GraphPad Prism 10. For the purification of the Retron-Eco7 complex, the gene encoding the ncRNA (144 nt) was amplified by PCR and cloned into a modified pACYCDuet-1 vector (Novagen) to construct pACYC-ncRNA (Supplementary Data 1). The operon encoding the RT (residues 1–311), PtuA (residues 1–550), and PtuB (residues 1–216) was amplified by PCR and cloned into the pET28a vector to construct pET-His6-RT–PtuA–PtuB-Twin-strep (PtuB with a C-terminal Twin-strep tag) (Supplementary Data 1). The genes encoding D15 (residues 1–291) and PtuA were individually cloned into a modified pE-SUMO vector with an N-terminal His6-SUMO tag (LifeSensors). To prepare mutants, mutations were introduced using a PCR-based method, and the sequences were confirmed by DNA sequencing. For the expression of the Retron-Eco7 complex (RT–ncRNA–PtuA–PtuB), E. coli BL21 (DE3) (Novagen) cells transformed with pACYC-ncRNA and pET-His6-RT–PtuA–PtuB-Twin-strep were cultured at 37 °C until the OD600 reached 0.8, and protein expression was then induced with 0.2 mM IPTG (Nacalai Tesque). The E. coli cells were further cultured at 18 °C overnight, harvested by centrifugation, resuspended in buffer A (20 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8.0, 300 mM NaCl, 3 mM 2-mercaptoethanol, and 1 mM PMSF), and lysed by sonication. The lysates were centrifuged, and the supernatant was applied to Strep-Tactin XT 4 Flow high-capacity resin (IBA). The complex was then eluted with buffer B (20 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8.0, 50 mM biotin, 300 mM NaCl, and 3 mM 2-mercaptoethanol). The complex was purified on a HiLoad 16/600 Superdex 200 pg column (Cytiva), equilibrated with buffer C (20 mM HEPES-NaOH, pH 7.5, 300 mM NaCl, and 1 mM DTT). To examine the stability of the Retron-Eco7 complex and its mutants, the complexes were purified by Strep-Tactin beads and then analyzed on a Superdex 200 Increase 10/300 GL column (Cytiva), equilibrated with buffer C (20 mM HEPES-NaOH, pH 7.5, 300 mM NaCl, and 1 mM DTT). The purified complex was stored at −80 °C until use, except for the cryo-EM analysis and tRNA cleavage assays, for which the freshly prepared complex was used without freezing. The protein concentration was measured using the Pierce 660-nm Protein Assay Reagent (Thermo Fisher Scientific). The synthetic tRNAs were purchased from Ajinomoto Bio-Pharma. For the expression of His6-SUMO tagged D15, E. coli Rosetta2 (DE3) (Novagen) cells were cultured at 37 °C in LB medium until the OD600 reached 0.8, and then induced with 0.2 mM IPTG and cultured overnight at 20 °C. The cells were harvested, resuspended in buffer D (20 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8.0, 20 mM imidazole, 1 M NaCl, 3 mM 2-mercaptoethanol, and 1 mM PMSF), and lysed by sonication. The lysates were centrifuged, and the supernatant was applied to Ni-NTA Superflow resin (QIAGEN) and eluted with buffer E (20 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8.0, 300 mM imidazole, 300 mM NaCl, and 3 mM 2-mercaptoethanol). After treatment with SUMO protease (prepared in-house), the protein was further purified on a HiTrap Heparin column (Cytiva), equilibrated with buffer F (50 mM HEPES-NaOH, pH 7.5, 150 mM NaCl, and 0.5 mM TCEP). The protein was eluted with a linear gradient of 0.15–2 M NaCl, and then further purified on a HiLoad 16/600 Superdex 200 pg column, equilibrated with buffer G (50 mM HEPES-NaOH, pH 7.5, 500 mM NaCl, and 1 mM DTT). The purified protein was stored at −80 °C until use. His6-SUMO tagged PtuA was expressed in E. coli and purified using Ni-NTA resin, following the same protocol as for D15. The protein was treated with SUMO protease, and then loaded onto a HiTrap Heparin column, equilibrated with buffer H (20 mM HEPES-NaOH, pH 7.5, 300 mM NaCl, and 1 mM DTT). The protein was eluted with a linear gradient of 0.3–2 M NaCl, and further purified on a Superose 6 Increase 10/300 GL column (Cytiva), equilibrated with buffer I (20 mM HEPES-NaOH, pH 7.5, 1 M NaCl, and 1 mM DTT). The purified protein was stored at −80 °C until use. The purified RT–msDNA–PtuA–PtuB complex (Retron-Eco7 complex) solution (5.0 mg/mL) was mixed with 0.25% (final concentration) CHAPSO (Nacalai Tesque). The mixture (3 μL) was immediately applied to freshly glow-discharged Au 300 mesh R1.2/1.3 grids (Quantifoil), using a Vitrobot Mark IV (FEI) at 4 °C, with a waiting time of 10 s and a blotting time of 6 s under 100% humidity conditions. The grids were plunge-frozen in liquid ethane cooled at liquid nitrogen temperature. Cryo-EM data were collected using a Titan Krios G3i microscope (Thermo Fisher Scientific), running at 300 kV and equipped with a Gatan Quantum-LS Energy Filter (GIF) and a Gatan K3 Summit direct electron detector in the correlated double sampling mode (The University of Tokyo, Japan). Movies were recorded at a nominal magnification of 105,000×, corresponding to a calibrated pixel size of 0.83 Å, with an electron exposure of 7.74 e−/pix/sec for 4.60 s, resulting in an accumulated exposure of 49.7 e−/Å2. The data were automatically acquired by the image shift method using the EPU software (Thermo Fisher Scientific), with a defocus range of −0.8 to −2.0 μm, and 7847 movies were acquired. Data processing was performed using the cryoSPARC v4.6.2 software package50. Dose-fractionated movies were aligned using Patch motion correction, and the contrast transfer function (CTF) parameters were approximated using Patch-Based CTF estimation with the default settings. Particles were automatically picked using Topaz Picker51. The picked particles were divided into five classes (states 1–5) by Heterogeneous Refinement with the default parameters, using the map derived from cryoSPARC Ab initio Reconstruction as the template. For states 1 and 2, masks were generated for the coiled-coil domain to further classify the conformational heterogeneity, and the selected particles after Heterogeneous Refinement were divided into three classes using 3D Classification without alignment. The best classes for states 1–5, containing 67,204, 125,237, 95,729, 93,471, and 180,392 particles, respectively, were refined using Non-uniform Refinement52 following Reference-Based Motion Correction. This refinement yielded maps with 2.75, 2.62, 2.70, 2.67, and 2.58-Å resolutions, respectively, according to the gold-standard Fourier shell correlation (FSC) = 0.143 criterion53. Local resolution was estimated using BlocRes in cryoSPARC54. The models of the Retron-Eco7 complex were automatically built using COOT55, starting from a model built by ModelAngelo56. The models were refined using Servalcat57 against unsharpened half maps, with structural restraints from AlphaFold 258 predictions processed by ProSMART59. The models were validated using MolProbity60. The statistics of the 3D reconstruction and model refinement are summarized in Supplementary Table 1. The molecular graphics and cryo-EM density map figures were prepared using CueMol (http://www.cuemol.org) or UCSF ChimeraX61. ATPase activities were measured using an NADH-coupled assay, at 37 °C in a 384-well plate. Each reaction (40 μL) contained 10 mM ATP and either 1 µM purified Retron-Eco7 complex (either WT, PtuA D395A, or PtuB H57A) or 1 µM PtuA alone, in a reaction buffer consisting of 20 mM HEPES-NaOH (pH 8.0), 150 mM NaCl, 2 mM MgCl2, 1 mM DTT, 0.3 mM NADH, 9 mM phosphoenolpyruvate, 60 µg/mL pyruvate kinase, and 32 µg/mL lactate dehydrogenase. Absorbance at 340 nm (A340) was measured every 1 min for 30 min using a SpectraMax iD5 plate reader (Molecular Devices) to monitor NADH oxidation coupled with ATP hydrolysis. Control reactions containing only 10 mM ATP (without protein) were used to correct for background NADH consumption from non-enzymatic ATP degradation. A340 values were converted to NADH concentrations using a calibration curve. ATPase activity (nmol ATP min−1 mg−1 protein) was calculated from the NADH oxidation rate (mM/min), determined from five data points between 15 and 20 min. Data were analyzed and plotted using GraphPad Prism 10. E. coli (DH10B) cells containing the pBAD-PtuA–PtuB plasmid were grown in 10 mL of LB medium to an OD600 of 0.3. Expression of PtuA–PtuB was induced with 0.2% L-arabinose, and the cultures were incubated at 37 °C for 1 h with shaking at 200 rpm. E. coli cells containing the empty pBAD vector (pKLC23) were used as the control. The cultures were then centrifuged at 6000 × g for 5 min, and the pellets were washed twice with PBS buffer. Total RNA was extracted using an miRNA isolation kit (Qiagen) following the manufacturer's instructions. For total RNA extraction from Retron-Eco7-expressing cells, E. coli cells containing the Retron-Eco7 plasmid or the empty vector (control) were infected with SP15 (MOI = 10) for 20 min. The cultures were then centrifuged at 10,000 × g for 10 min, and the pellets were washed twice with SM buffer. Total RNA was extracted using the miRNA isolation kit. The extracted RNA samples were used for tRNA-fragment sequencing. tRNA-fragment sequencing was performed by Filgen, Inc. and Arraystar Inc. (Project codes: J_041823-tRF&tiRNAseq-8 and J_102623-tRF&tiRNA-seq-8, respectively). Total RNA samples were initially assessed for integrity using agarose gel electrophoresis. RNA concentrations and protein contamination were measured using a NanoDrop ND-1000 spectrophotometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific), and RNA quality was further evaluated using an Agilent 2100 Bioanalyzer (Agilent Technologies). To ensure efficient library preparation, RNA samples were pretreated to remove specific modifications that could interfere with the process. These treatments included deacylation of 3′-aminoacyl RNA to 3′-OH, removal of 3′-cP (2′,3′-cyclic phosphate) to generate 3′-OH, phosphorylation of 5′-OH to 5′-P, and demethylation of m1A and m3C to facilitate efficient reverse transcription. Library preparation was performed using a NEBNext® Multiplex Small RNA Library Prep Set for Illumina® (New England Biolabs). The workflow included 3′-adapter ligation, 5′-adapter ligation, cDNA synthesis, PCR amplification, and size selection of PCR products between 134 and 160 bp, corresponding to 14–40 nt small RNAs. The quality and quantity of the libraries were assessed using the Agilent 2100 Bioanalyzer, and equal amounts of each library were pooled based on quantification results. The pooled libraries were denatured with 0.1 M NaOH to produce single-stranded DNA molecules, diluted to a final concentration of 1.8 pM, and sequenced on an Illumina platform following the manufacturer's protocols. Sequencing quality was evaluated using FastQC. Adapter sequences were trimmed from raw reads using Cutadapt62. Processed reads were aligned to mature tRNA sequences, allowing for one mismatch. Reads that did not align to mature tRNAs were subsequently mapped to precursor tRNA sequences using Bowtie63. Unmapped reads were further aligned to miRNA reference sequences using miRDeep264. Expression profiles of tRNA-derived fragments were quantified based on the mapped read counts. E. coli (DH10B) cells containing either the empty vector, the Retron-Eco7 plasmid, or the Retron-Eco7 mutant plasmids were left uninfected or infected with the SP15 or SP15m phage for 20 min (MOI = 10). The cells were then centrifuged at 10,000 × g for 10 min and resuspended in 1 mL of RNA isolation reagent (40% (w/v) phenol, 1% (v/v) ethylene glycol, 2 M guanidine thiocyanate, 0.1% (w/v) 8-quinolinol, 20 mM tri-sodium citrate dihydrate, 0.1 M NaOAc, pH 4.5, 0.1% (v/v) Triton X-100, 0.2% (w/v) N-lauroylsarcosine sodium salt, 50 mM salicylic acid, 10 mM aluminon, and 0.0001% (w/v) bromophenol blue). After vigorous shaking at 4 °C for 20 min, chloroform was added to the solution at a concentration of 20%. The mixture was centrifuged at 20,000 × g at 4 °C for 10 min, and the aqueous phase was collected. Total RNA was recovered from the aqueous phase by 2-propanol precipitation. Total RNA (4 μg) was resolved by electrophoresis on a 10% polyacrylamide gel containing 7 M urea, stained with ethidium bromide, blotted onto a nylon membrane (Amersham Hybond N+; Cytiva), dried, and cross-linked by UV (254 nm, 120 mJ/cm2). The DNA probe for each tRNA (Supplementary Data 1) was 5′-labeled with [γ-32P] ATP (PerkinElmer) using T4 polynucleotide kinase (Toyobo). The membrane was subjected to hybridization at 53 °C overnight in hybridization buffer (500 mM sodium phosphate buffer, pH 7.4, 7.5% SDS, 5% polyethylene glycol 6000, 1 mM EDTA-NaOH, pH 8.0, and 0.5% casein) and 4 pmol of 5′-32P-radiolabeled DNA probe. The membrane was washed three times with SSC (150 mM NaCl and 15 mM sodium citrate, pH 7.0), dried, and exposed to an imaging plate (BAS-MS2040; Fujifilm) to visualize the hybridization bands, using an FLA-7000 imaging analyzer (Cytiva). Uncropped images are available in Source Data. E. coli cells carrying the Retron-Eco7 plasmid were infected with the SP15m phage (MOI = 1) and cultured overnight in 4 mL of LB medium at 37 °C with shaking at 200 rpm. Afterwards, the lysate was centrifuged at 5000 × g for 10 min and filtered through a 0.2 μm membrane. To screen for potential escaper phage, 100 μL of the filtered phage solution, containing both wild-type and escaper phages, was mixed with 100 μL of cultured E. coli carrying either the Retron-Eco7 plasmid or the empty vector. The mixture was combined with 4 mL of LB top agar and poured onto LB plates, and the plates were then incubated overnight at 37 °C. Single plaques formed on the Retron-Eco7-containing cells were identified as escaper mutants. To purify these escaper mutants, individual escaping plaques were propagated, and phage titers were subsequently determined using a plaque assay as described previously25. The purified escaper phages were then tested in plaque assays with E. coli cells containing either the Retron-Eco7 plasmid or the empty vector. High-titer phage lysates (> 107 PFU/mL) of the mutant phages were used for DNA extraction. The phage lysate (500 μL) was treated with DNase I (3 U/mL) and RNase A (20 ng/mL) (both from Takara), and incubated at 37 °C for 1 h to degrade bacterial DNA and RNA. Phage DNA was then extracted using a Phage DNA Extraction Kit (Norgen Biotek Corp.) following the manufacturer's protocols. Whole-genome sequencing was performed by Macrogen Japan, Inc. Bioinformatic analysis was performed using CLC Genomic Workbench (QIAGEN), with silent mutations in protein-coding regions excluded from this analysis. The identified escaper phages are listed in Supplementary Data 1. To examine D15-mediated msDNA cleavage, the purified Retron-Eco7 complex (100 nM) was incubated with the purified WT D15 (100 nM) or its mutants (R86L and R86Q) (100 nM) at 37 °C for 1, 5, and 30 min, in 10 μL of reaction buffer (20 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.5, 150 mM NaCl, 2 mM MgCl2, and 1 mM DTT). To examine D15-mediated DNA and RNA cleavage, the purified WT D15 (100 nM) was incubated with either single-stranded DNA (200 nM), double-stranded DNA (200 nM), or single-stranded RNA (200 nM) at 37 °C for 10 min. The reactions were quenched with Proteinase K (Nacalai Tesque) in denaturing buffer containing 7 M urea, and analyzed by 15% urea-PAGE. The gels were stained with SYBR Gold Nucleic Acid Gel Stain (Thermo Fisher Scientific), and then visualized using the FUSION Solo S imaging system (Vilber Bio Imaging). All experiments were performed at least three times. To investigate the dissociation of the Retron-Eco7 complex by D15 treatment, the purified Retron-Eco7 complex (210 nM) was incubated with the purified WT D15 (210 nM) at 37 °C for 10 min, in 400 μL of reaction buffer (20 mM HEPES-NaOH, pH 7.5, 150 mM NaCl, 2 mM MgCl2, and 1 mM DTT). The reaction mixture was then fractionated on a Superdex 200 Increase 10/300 GL column. Peak fractions were analyzed by SDS-PAGE and urea-PAGE. The gels were stained with Bullet CBB Stain One (Nacalai Tesque) and SYBR Gold, respectively, and then visualized using the FUSION Solo S imaging system. All experiments were performed at least three times. 5′-Cy5-labeled Ec-tRNATyr (200 nM) was incubated with the purified Retron-Eco7 complex (500 nM) with or without D15 (500 nM) at 37 °C for 60 min, in 10 μL of reaction buffer (20 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.5, 150 mM NaCl, 2 mM MgCl2, and 1 mM DTT). 5′-Cy5-labeled targets (Ajinomoto Bio-Pharma), including Ec-tRNATyr (200 nM), SP-tRNATyr (200 nM), ssDNA (200 nM), dsDNA (200 nM), or ssRNA (200 nM), were also incubated with the Retron-Eco7 complex (250, 500, or 1000 nM) at 37 °C for 60 min. The reactions were quenched with Proteinase K in denaturing buffer containing 7 M urea, and then analyzed on 15% urea-PAGE gels (Invitrogen). The tRNAs and their fragments were visualized by the Cy5 fluorescence with the FUSION Solo S system. All experiments were performed at least three times. E. coli (DH10B) cells, containing either the arabinose-inducible Retron-Eco7 (pKLC23-Eco7) or the arabinose-inducible PtuA and PtuB (pKLC23-PtuA–PtuB), along with the anhydrotetracycline-inducible D15 (pKLC83-D15) plasmid (Supplementary Data 1), were cultured overnight. The cultures were then serially diluted tenfold in LB medium. A 3 μL aliquot of each dilution was spotted onto LB agar plates. Expression of Retron-Eco7 or PtuA–PtuB, and D15 was induced by supplementing the plates with 0.2% L-arabinose and 50 ng/mL anhydrotetracycline, respectively. The empty pKLC23 and pKLC83 vectors were used as controls. The plates were incubated overnight at 37 °C, and colony growth was evaluated the following day. Sample sizes were determined based on those used in our previous studies and similar published work that yielded reproducible results. For cryo-EM analyses, particle images that did not improve map quality were excluded using standard classification procedures in cryoSPARC. All biochemical, cellular, and functional assays were conducted with independent replicates following widely accepted protocols in the field (three biological or technical replicates unless otherwise stated). Data are generally presented as the mean ± SD of three or four independent replicates (n  =  3 or 4), and no statistical analysis was performed. All experiments were independently repeated at least three times with similar results, confirming reproducibility. No randomization was performed for biochemical and cellular experiments because these assays involve inherently uniform and controllable samples, such as purified proteins or cell cultures, where variability is minimal compared with live animals. No blinding was performed for biochemical and cellular experiments, as these experiments involve objective measurements under controlled conditions that are not influenced by subjective assessments. Further information on research design is available in the Nature Portfolio Reporting Summary linked to this article. The structure models of the Retron-Eco7 complexes have been deposited in the Protein Data Bank under the following accession codes: 9KJX (state 1), 9KJY (state 2), 9KJZ (state 3), 9KK1 (state 4), and 9KK2 (state 5). The cryo-EM density maps of the Retron-Eco7 complexes have been deposited in the Electron Microscopy Data Bank under the accession codes EMD-62378 (state 1), EMD-62379 (state 2), EMD-62380 (state 3), EMD-62381 (state 4), and EMD-62382 (state 5). The raw images have also been deposited in the Electron Microscopy Public Image Archive, under the accession code EMPIAR-12477. The genome sequence of SP15 is available in the NCBI database under accession number NC_048627 (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/nuccore/1859677195). The raw and processed data from the tRNA fragment sequencing are available in the Gene Expression Omnibus (GEO) repository under accession number GSE293394. Source data are provided with this paper. A.H.A. is supported by the Japan Agency for Medical Research and Development (AMED) (Grant Number JP23wm0325065) and JSPS KAKENHI (Grant Number 23K13876). WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


Iridium(III)-catalysed ionic hydrogenation of pyridines to multisubstituted piperidines
Source: Nature    Published: 2025-12-02 10:22:19

Thank you for visiting nature.com. You are using a browser version with limited support for CSS. To obtain the best experience, we recommend you use a more up to date browser (or turn off compatibility mode in Internet Explorer). In the meantime, to ensure continued support, we are displaying the site without styles and JavaScript. Advertisement Nature Chemistry (2025)Cite this article Piperidine and pyridine are nitrogen heterocyclic motifs prominently used in pharmaceuticals and consequently of great importance. The direct reduction of planar pyridines into piperidines with high sp3-carbon content is highly attractive as this offers a route to producing high-value products and broadening the structural space. However, direct hydrogenation of pyridines with homogeneous catalysts is challenging due to their aromatic stability and catalyst-poisoning abilities. Here we describe a robust and selective iridium(III)-catalysed ionic hydrogenation of pyridines to corresponding functionalized piperidines. Important highly reduction-sensitive groups, including nitro, azido, bromo, alkenyl and alkynyl, are inert, enabling access to a broad range of multisubstituted piperidines in high yields, substantially expanding the available chemical space for this relevant scaffold. The method requires low catalyst loadings, is scalable to decagrams and delivers the most synthetically valuable free secondary amines as easily isolable and stable piperidinium salts. Applied in a complex late-stage setting, the pyridine motif in several FDA-approved drugs was successfully and selectively hydrogenated. This is a preview of subscription content, access via your institution Access Nature and 54 other Nature Portfolio journals Get Nature+, our best-value online-access subscription $32.99 / 30 days cancel any time Subscribe to this journal Receive 12 print issues and online access $259.00 per year only $21.58 per issue Buy this article USD 39.95 Prices may be subject to local taxes which are calculated during checkout The data generated in this study are provided in Supplementary Information.
